description.text: USS Joseph P. Kennedy, Jr. (DD-850) is a United States Navy Gearing-class destroyer. The ship was named after Lieutenant Joseph P. Kennedy, Jr., a naval aviator, son of the former Ambassador to Britain, Joseph P. Kennedy, Sr., and older brother of future President John F. Kennedy. Joseph P. Kennedy, Jr. served, with interruptions for modernization, until 1973. Among the highlights of her service are the blockade of Cuba during the Cuban Missile Crisis and the afloat recovery teams for Gemini 6 and Gemini 7.

author: sarman_1998

description.text:
These are disposable mounting tab for 1.3" OLED display such as the Heltec models that can found on ebay. The are inserted between the display and the main PCB are riveted with the side of a hot solder iron. The model is customized but the default STL calls for two 3mm drills on the main PCB. The mounts are eccentric to simplify the printing and this requires the PCB hole to be slightly offset from the center line of the two mounting holes of the display. The mounts are used in only two of the 4 holes of the display since the other side is secured by the header pins soldered to the main PCB.  
I printed mine using black PLA on a MakerFarm's prusa I3V using 0.4mm nozzle and 0.2mm layers sliced by Cura. You may need to tweak the dimensions to match the tolerances of your printer.

This is an upside-down LEGO crystal made on Tinkercad designed to hang from the bottom of a brick.

I made this because I recently purchased a roll of igus.de's iglidur i170-PEtribifilament for a project and I needed something for the filament to roll on as I fed it to the printer.   
It's not fancy but it works. The STL file contains all you need except #16 x 1.25" Wire Nails to hold the rollers in place.  
For best results print at .2 layer. I found the nails to be a little loose but a drop of glue on the tips took care of that.

title: A Printable Microscope Focus Lock Upgrade

description.text: This is an upgrade to the printable microscope (77450) that allows the user to lock the focus. This is useful if you find the focus difficult to hold due to the weight of the optics tube or if you plan to use a smart phone adapter (coming soon). This upgrade is designed with a tapered nut that is installed from the inside of the head so that adhesives are not required to hold the assembly together. The nut is built separate from the head so that the thread can be reproduced with the best fidelity using fused filament fabrication. The original microscope can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:77450

I printed all the parts using the MakerWare high setting, 0.1mm layers and 15% fill on a MakerBot Replicator 2. Once printed, install the nut from the inside of the head and thread the screw. You should then be able to install the remaining parts from the original design (not included here). Good luck!

author: kwalus

description.text: I needed to extend some stool legs to fit a non-standard size bar so whipped up these glides to fit into the standard 1/2" EMT pipe I used to do it. The 8.3-deg glide angle was set to match my barstools, but it should work through customizer for angles between 0 and 20+ deg without issue. Here's a link to the 90-degree flat remix, since that is such a common need: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:865392

title: Compact Bowden Extruder Drive for One/Two Up (modified)

description.text:
This is a remix of MacAttak's remix of an extruder driver.  I included my .scad file but it will be very difficult to see what is going on (I had trouble with the original).  See MacAttak's version of this thing for the .scad file I worked from.  NOTE: I replaced the .scad file - I had earlier uploaded a shortcut instead of the actual file - fixed now.  
The idler lever was not modified so I just included the original STL file.  The base was heavily modified to accept a 1/8NPT Push Fit Bowden connector, and to easily mount to the top plate of the One/Two Up.  
Important Note:  When you mount this to the top plate of the One/TwoUP, slide it about 3mm to the outside before drilling your holes.  I didn't, so I've lost about 30mm of print height until I shift mine (OR shave 2-3mm off the left side of the MDF holding the z-screw nut - probably what I'll do).

You will need 2 additional 4mm bolts (about 13-15 mm long with nuts) to bolt this to the top plate of the One/Two Up.  
You won't have enough room to use a regular tap to tap the NPT threads, but if you are careful and go slowly, you can tap the hole with the bowden connector (I used a small clamp to keep the layers from delaminating as I applied pressure).

title: FlashForge Creator Pro bed leveling jig

description.text: Inspired by this jig http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:810220, this is used to level a FlashForge 3D Creator Pro bed using a Harbor Freight digital indicator (SKU #93295).

• Initiate bed leveling procedure.
  • After extruder finds home, attach jig across guide bars with the slotted part of the jig on the back guide bar.
  • Place dial indicator in top of hole and push it down all of the way until the dial face housing touches the top of the jig.
  • Turn on dial indicator and place piece of paper or business card between dial indicator tip and bed, then zero the indicator.
  • Remove paper and note measurement.
  • Use that measurement as your guide to leveling the bed.

comments.text: Thanks for this jig, it works very nicely. I printed it on its side to save needing supports. It should work with any dial indicator having a standard .375" shaft and at least 1" travel. I have two analog (Craftex and Shars) and one digital (iGaging) indicator and they all fit equally well. Of course, analog indicators allow more precise readings so that's what I prefer to use. I first adjust one setpoint with a feeler gauge to get the correct nozzle clearance and then use this to measure its depth and set the rest. I also used it to quickly confirm my suspicion that my bed isn't perfectly flat (0.002" high in the centre). I would strongly recommend attaching the indicator before placing this on the rails though because it's a good tight fit and applying that much force to the rails is not a good thing.
comments.author: pcman

comments.text: @pcman "I would strongly recommend attaching the indicator before placing this on the rails though because it's a good tight fit and applying that much force to the rails is not a good thing."

comments.text: Other than minimizing the complexity or print time. Is there a particular reason you chose to offset the dial indicator mounting hole near one of the rails instead of dead center between them?

comments.text: No, not really.  It helped to minimize the print because I was able to combine the part surrounding the hole into the part holding the bar.  Otherwise I would have had to move it over and possibly add some more bulk to the area surrounding the hole to make it sturdy.  Either way should work.  Feel free to mod and provide any improvements.  I'm always open to suggestions.

comments.text: Actually I think the design is spot on. The offset for the dial indicator avoids the track and puts the actual probe much closer to the area where the hotend will touch. I like how heavy it is as it helps keep it connected to the bar nicely. Thanks for sharing this!

author: xdod

title: Orange Rx 3 channel S.Bus receiver with long antenna leads holder

description.text:
If you make one, please post a photo!  
A nice little protective housing and 90 degree antenna holder for one of the under appreciated but pretty awesome Spectrum compatible Rx units, the 3 channel (14 channel with S.Bus!) this holder has 2 ports for antenna tubes that allow you to easily offset the antennas and holds the tubes VERY tightly. my antenna tubes are 3mm wide. be sure yours are very close to this or you may not get the tubes in. Everything should fit very tight.  
In order to get the spacings right i had to adjust and re-print several times. (note the picture) My wasted plastic is your gain!

To get your antennas through the small holes you may need to run a string or wire loop in and then put the antenna leads through it, then pull the loop up to get the antenna leads started up the holes.  
the fit for the receiver is pretty tight but you should be able to get it in without too much force. if you find yourself having to push too hard, re-print this scaled up 1% or something.  
I'm not responsible for any issues you encounter due to using this item. Use any of my designs at your own risk. Have Fun!

The standard pen holding section of the modular pen stand with a void in the middle so you can pause the print and add weight (pennies, lead fishing weights, bbs, etc). The hole for adding ballast ends around 32.1 mm before it starts to taper in, so you need to divide by your layer height, and that will give you the layer you need to pause the print on.

After miserably failing at using zip ties to set up a webcam on my printer I figured it was time to make a solid mount for it. This webcam mount was made for a Logitech C510 but can probably be used on other webcams. The design is based on Auzze's webcam mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8350 Auzze's seemed solid however the screw on the camera side of the mount would not work for my camera. So I changed the screw placing around and in the process created a parametric camera mount scad file. Most of the settings are clearly marked and can be changed. However, the scad file needs the OpenSCAD Parts Library found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6021

Print.
Clean up if needed.
Tighten the shorter clamp to your printer.
Tighten your webcam to the other side.
Now stream!

Printed in ABS at 240 C(nozzle) and 100 C(printbed).
100% infill with brim and 50 mm s print speed.

A set of 3D print profiles for MakerBot Slicer in MakerWare. The purpose is to easily visualise how dense the following different infill percentages
  • No roof layer - 0% infill
  • No roof layer - 5% infill
  • No roof layer - 10% infill
  • No roof layer - 15% infill
  • No roof layer - 25% infill
  • No roof layer - 50% infill
  • No roof layer - 100% infill
    The 3D model is simply a scaled-up (3 mm) version of the built-in large helper disk in MakerWare. (http://www.makerbot.com/makerware)
    We attached the x3g print files which you can copy to an SD card and 3D print with PLA plastic on a MakerBot Replicator 2 3D printer.
    The ready-made 3D print profiles are adapted in MakerBot Slicer so that no roof is made. This leaves the top open and exposes the infill.
    To achieve a clear visualisation the model was made of two contrasting plastic colours.
    • Thing video
  • http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fhv2TvBUyQs
    • By Creative Tools

  • Home - Things - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instructables - Instagram - Flickr - Vimeo - LinkedIn

• Download the file "No roof layer - Infill profies.zip"
  • Unpack the file. You will se several folders
  • Copy them to your computers /user-home-folder/Things/Profies
  • Download the file "Helper_Disk_Large_3_mm_height.thing"
  • Start MakerWare and open the thing file. You will see a small disk
  • Press the Make-button
  • From the "Profile" drop-down menu, make sure you see the following added profiles
    • No roof layer - 0% infill
    • No roof layer - 5% infill
    • No roof layer - 10% infill
    • No roof layer - 15% infill
    • No roof layer - 25% infill
    • No roof layer - 50% infill
    • No roof layer - 100% infill
  • Choose a preferred profile
  • Start the 3D print and use a bright PLA plastic colour
  • Via the built-in LCD panel on the Replicator 2 using the arrow keys, choose Change filament.
  • Wait until the the 3D printer prints the forth layer and just before it finishes this layer, press the M button on the Replicator 2.
  • Proceed and change the filament as usual to a darker colour.
  • Resume the 3D print
  • After it finishes you will see the disk with no top layers and all the infill exposed! :)
    MAKE YOUR OWN ADAPTED PROFILE
    If you wish to make your own adapted profile as we did, please do as follows.
  • Start MakerWare
  • Add any STL file into the scene
  • Press the Make button
  • Choose Advanced Options
  • Press Create Profile
  • From the drop-down menu, choose MakerBot Slicer PLA Template
  • Choose a name for your roofless profile
  • Press Create
  • Press Edit Profile
  • A text editor window should open and show all the profile settings
  • In the line ("infillDensity": 0.1), edit the 0.1-value and change it to the amount of infill you desire. 0 means no infill and 1 means 100%.
  • In the line ("roofThickness" : 1.2), change the value 1.2 to 0 (zero). This will tell Slicer to disregard the top layers by making them 0 mm in height.
  • Save and close the file
  • Test print your new profile! :)
    Fore detailed instructions on how to edit MakerBot Slicer settings, check out this URL: http://www.makerbot.com/support/makerware/documentation/slicer/

title: Dremel 395 Holder (V2) for table top or vise

description.text:
Fits Dremel brand 100 series, 200 series and model 395. Improved? version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:822387
Need to hold your Dremel tool in a vise. This holder does. Slides over the 47mm round, 32mm long section. Set into your bench vise and snug it up. Now you have a bench mounted cutoff tool. I could not live without it. Now I don't have to.
Holder is 28mm long. Updated version has mounting holes for #8 x 3/4 sheet metal screws and pinch bolt to clamp the Dremel tool. Pinch bolt is #6 x 2. Also need a #6 nut. Available on ebay
http://www.ebay.com/itm/201369687706?var=&ssPageName=STRK:MESELX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1558.l2649

Printed on PrintRBot Plus in about an hour. 2 perimeters, 2 layers top and bottom. Infill at 20%. Oriented with big hole flat to the platform.  See photo.  
Vise mounting does not need the pinch bolt.  
Run the #6 x 1-1/2 screw thru to clear the hole. Back up screw, drop the nut in and thread screw into nut. Insert Dremel and tighten the screw. Snug the screw. Crank too hard may crush plastic.  
Flange holes take #8 x 3/4 sheet metal screws. Mount on a 2 x 4, 1 x 4 or anything else. Flange could be C clamped to edge of table.

title: IGUS RJMP 01-08 8mm Bushing Holder for Prusa I3 Y Axis

description.text: I decided to upgrade to IGUS RJMP 01-08 8mm bushings from the cheap Chinese bearings I previously had. This will mount onto a Prusa I3 Y Axis. It is printed vertically for maximum strength. The measurements for the hole are 24mm x 18mm center to center. I just uploaded a revised version.  After I printed the bushing holder I realized the nut traps were oblonged and the hole for bushing was a little to small.
I printed this in ABS at .3mm layer height and 3 perimeters. The bushing should be pressed in and fit snugly.

description.text:
This simple printed part allows a Pilot G2 pen to be attached to the printer so 2d pictures can be plotted on a piece of paper.
The part is threaded to fit a pilot G2 pen. When inserted upside down the pen benefits from the spring allowing constant pressure on the paper even if the bed isn’t perfectly level. Since the part is threaded, you can adjust the pen’s pressure simply by turning the pen top. Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tWuR4tzgNO4

You only print the first layer of the print. I just simply pause the print after the first layer and remove the pen and paper. Print WITH supports at .3mm with either the 4 legs on the surface of the bed or the barrel shaft on the print bed. Adjustment to slicer settings:
Layer height: .1mm
Speed: ~60mm/s
Skirt: Disable
Brim: Disable
Nozzle Diameter: .2mm
Lift Z (Z hop): 2mm
Turn of the extruder heat
Pull filament out of printer or select “DRY RUN” in repetier host.

title: Darksoft CPS2 Multi LCD/Control Panel Enclosure

description.text:
This is an enclosure for the LCD/Control panel of Darksoft's CPS2 Arcade Multi Kit (plays CPS2 arcade games on original hardware from an SD card).  I wanted to mount this control panel in the coin door of my arcade game, but needed something to hold it in place, and protect it from damage.  
Simply print this, put the control panel into the enclosure, and screw it shut.  You can optionally print the bracket if you'd like it to sit upright.  
The case is held together using 4x 1/2" 4-40 countersunk screws.  I simply used velcro to mount this inside my coin door, though there are also holes in the bracket so it can be mounted with screws.  
I attached the STL files, as well as the Sketchup model (one with and without the text/logos).

I printed all three pieces in black ABS using my standard ABS settings (at 0.3mm layer height).  
The text/logos on the face are just slightly indented, and I printed it with no support material (so it simply spanned the gaps).  
As usual, my printer made the holes slightly smaller than modeled, so I manually widened some of them a bit as necessary after the print finished.  
Insert the control panel into the case, and screw it shut with 4x 1/2" #4 countersunk screws.  
Attach enclosure however desired (velcro, screws, etc)... if desired.

title: Candle Holder Numbers - Numbers 0 - 9 for Birthday Cake Decoration
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The range of 'Candle Holder Numbers' provides a great 'year appropriate' decorative centre piece for a Birthday Cake. Numbers 0 - 9 have been provided as .stl's so you can make any combination of years being celebrated. Unlike the number candles you can buy in a shop you can print these in your choice of colours to suit the cakes decoration.... and they are reusable. Just place regular Birthday Candles in the hole in the top of each number (Obviously you can place additional candles around the cake to reflect the year as well if you want).   
At standard scale each number is 10mm thick then has a border of another 2.5mm which can be printed in a second colour. Just pause your machine at around 87% when it starts creating the raised areas (Z-Pause at 12mm on a Replicator 2 with a 1.0mm Raft).   
The 'Candle Holder Numbers' have been designed to take standard 5mm diameter Birthday Candles so do not scale up or down as it will affect whether or not the candles fit or stand up well. However, if you have candles of a different diameter you can easily scale the numbers to suit.   
Each number is approx. 60mm tall at standard size and has a prong on the base to ensure it stands up securely when fully inserted into a cake.   
Note: If you like this check out my other designs!
Recommend to print each 'Candle Holder Number' with Raft (for easy removal from your build plate) at standard 0.20mm resolution and 15%

title: FlashForge Creator/Pro/X/Dreamer Extruder plastic. Works with Flex Filament. Also works with the Monoprice 3d printer and MicroCenter's PowerSpec. Now compatible with CTC with new version.

description.text:
Update 1/28/16:
Modified base to allow easier access to drive gear set screw from behind the spring. Addeded CTC version. CTC uses a larger diameter spring so the hole has be enlarged to fit this bigger spring. Update 7/20/15, the other day I made a video on how to install this.
It is my first youtube video ever so go easy. :-)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BXY1MxEjYt0 I've been working on this one for a while and finally finished a few details and tuning the spring tension. Features of this design are: 1. only 2 pieces to print per side. 2. Uses brass bushing from the original plastic. 3. Fully supports Flex filament like Ninja flex and Fila Flex with no jamming. I know there have been a couple change in the filament drive gear recently. Let me know if any adjustments need to be made. This version is based off the original straight drive gear. I have seen some newer ones with a rim on both sides and due to the tight fit of the drive gear it might rub. Easy fix, I just don't have any of the other drive gears at the moment to test fit. Leave a comment on how this works out for you. Thanks.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator X/Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

95-100

The base should be printed flat with supports. The Lever can be printed a couple ways. I print it upside down with the filament hole toward the bed using a little support. Try not to let supports go inside the holes. After printing you will want to mount the plastic without the filament drive gear and pinch roller installed, but use the spring to hold tension. Then use a 2mm drill bit to slightly enlarge and smooth/clear the filament path. The filament drive gear can be installed with the plastic in place. Use a 2mm allen wrench and slip behind the spring to tighten set screw. The filament pinch roller installs from the side. Use a 3mm x 10mm flat head socket screw to mount. Print in ABS. If you like my work consider purchasing an upgraded extruder mount. http://store.wmdproducts.com/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=62 Shameless plug. :-)

author: nagato

description.text:
Garmin Fenix 3 Quick Release Band and Quarter Turn Mounts. Very simple design, computer / watch body snaps into QR mounts.
. QR Band Mount works great with NATO bands. (Pictures soon)
.
QR QT Mount works with Garmin's Quarter Turn Bike Mount or watch band. The mount was designed for easy print, and requires two M2x8mm cap screws & nuts (available online or find at local hobby store). Line up the holes and acetone weld or appropriate super glue should work also. .
Thanks to user WheresWaldo for creating a usuable quarter turn plate:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:656833

General mount usage:
  • Computer watch body snaps into the prongs. Insert left side then the right side.
  • To remove, grab the center of the computer, pull while releasing the two right side tabs (simultaneously). Get's easier after a few tries.
  • Tip: Keep the spring bars on the computer body, loop the NATO strap through for added security.
    .
    .
    QR QT Mount Assembly:
  • Print QT and the QR Mount
  • Use M2x8mm cap screws and nuts to attach the pieces together. The nuts might be a tight fit in the openings, use the screw to set the nut in place. 8mm length screws should provide a flush fit.

Protective shield for a Fatshark-type FPV minicam. The shield portion is tilted upward at a 4-degree angle to aid in keeping the horizon in view during forward flight in a quadcopter. The mount should be able to accommodate any FPV-type camera with base dimensions of about 22 mm square x 30 mm long max. There are 2 stl files - the "FS" version is meant for a Fatshark cam (it has a cutout in the back for the connector). The other stl file has a solid back. UPDATE 6/23/15: During my tests of the Fatshark version, I realized that there is not enough surface on the back wall for securely mounting via double-sided tape (due to the cutout for the connector). So I incorporated barneyj's simple Fatshark camera clip (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:841947) into my design.

Print and use!  
There are screw holes on the bottom of the base you can use to secure the mount to a surface.  If you use screws you need to install them before the camera (well at least the one within the barrel portion).  
I simply double-stick tape my camera to the back wall of the mount.   
For the Fatshark with clip version, the clip is intended to hold the cam in place without the use of tape.
This is one of my favorite all-time logos. The beautiful Zenithlogo.

title: An E3D Chimera Bracket for Ooznest Prusa i3 Version2

description.text: Since making the last bracket I have updated the design to include a couple of layer fans, they attach to the bracket by a single screw and nut. The bracket is slightly wider and there is still plenty of room for air circulation.

1> Screw the bracket and x-carriage together.
2> Mount the assembly on the x-rods.
3> Screw the Chimera to the bracket and zip-tie the cables to the sides of the bracket.
4> Screw each fan shroud to the bracket.
5> Screw a fan to each fan shroud.

You need a place to put your things, right? Do you have a pegboard? Do you have things that love flat surfaces? Well, then... here you go!
The STL file is set up for a 75mm deep shelf, 1/4 inch pegboard holes, and a 1 inch peg spacing. You'll need to edit the OpenSCAD file to change this.

If you don't like the defaults in the STL file, open this up in OpenSCAD, adjust the variables at the top, Compile & Render, then export as STL and reopen. Now you can print more stuff knowing you have a place to put it!
Once it's printed, you have two choices: put it into the pegboard while it's still warm (it will go in more easily but probably won't come out easily, and you run the risk of warping it), or let it cool, in which case you'll need a bit more force to get it in.

comments.author: tpchuckles

comments.text: Hi, to your first question, I think it might be difficult to make perfect right angle s curves, since the handle of the tube bender is in the way of the tube then. Usually the tube shouldnt bend. Maybe you have a low wallthickness. An easy trick to avoid this is to fill the tube up with water, and put it in the freezer. Then when the tube is filled with ice, it will prevent the tube from collapsing. While bending the tube you will barely notice the ice, then when the tube is in the right shape, just leave it outside and the ice will melt and let the water drip out. Then you have a perfectly bend tube. (Some people also use fine sand, but for small diameters I think ice is better, plus sand scratches the inside walls)

title: GL-3X 3 Axis Brushless Gimbal Modified For Xiaomi Yi

description.text:
Yi doesn't fit to the original camera carriage that comes with GL-3X. I guess I could file the edges, but since the controller is located exactly where the TV Out cable goes to, I couldn't use TV out. So I designed this. It's my first design and it took me more then a week and 600gr ABS to perfect the design. I lost count of failed prototypes. Few Notes:
1)Triangular-ish shape at the back is there for balance.
2)No screw holes to mount controller. You can use original screws to tread a hole. Or use hot glue.
3)Camera is friction fitted. It sits quite snugly. I shook it quite forcefully. Didn't budge. If you want extra security, you could use velcro.
4)All the interface ports(both for Camera and Controller) are open except for HDMI out. I don't need that port. So I used there to add some extra weight to the back.
5)It weights a few grams less then the original piece.

I used ABS.Don't know if it'd work with PLA.
-240C hotend 100C bed temp.
-Layer height 0.3
-Infill 100%
-NEEDS Supports.
-Print it as it is in the stl file.
-Use M3 nut and ~5mm bolt to tighten carriage to the motor shaft. You might need to clean the hole first.

title: Bowden Conversion - Prusa i3 X Carriage Adapter for Bulldog XL Extruder

description.text:
This X carriage adapter will allow you to use the E3D bowden extruder. The hole spacing for the modules has been kept the same so that you can use any modules designed for the original:
• Prusa i3 X Carriage Adapter for Bulldog XL Extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:458308)
So far this includes the fan duct and both of the Z probe designs. Requirements

• 1x small cable tie,
• M3 screws - amount and length depends on modules used. Refer to the original adapter linked above.

author: AugustusXXV

description.text:
I'm not sure what name should I give, stepper motor bracket, stepper motor wire clamp or something. By the way, this design is actually for my hot end cable and to fix it in place because there might be a chance that the hot end might become loose due to slight stress from the wire moving back and forth. The clamp size are measured around 5mm, which clamps the teflon wire cover. Also suitable mainly for Geeetech single extruder style and for other purposes of mounting this on any stepper motor for some cable management. For mine, I added extra platform so I could stick my led array there but it kept falling off (using foam double sided tape) Update
I added several design to the cap, one has flat end until the clamp, one is flat same thickness as the flat surface of 2mm, another is 3 point open end so you can mount it anyway you like it

Can be printed with 10% infill, 3 wall and 4 tops/bottom.
This is to ensure the other end still offers flexibility especially mine with pla plastic For geeetech owner, do make sure to limit your max X axis movement because this bracket can hit the z axis threaded rod. Mine limited up to 185mm without any offsets from endstops You might be having trouble putting on m3x24 nut at lower back, I suggest you mount it from the back and use pliers to hold the nut while turning the screw

description.text:
Bearing for supporting a downward load.
Requires 7 x 9.5 mm ball bearings. key features:
1) Screw holes for easy fixing to whatever.
2) Easy to assemble and disassemble but with anti self loosening mechanism.

comments.text: This works well with 9.5mm ball bearings I had purchased from Amazon.  I had to sand down the underside of the screw head a little bit to get it to sit flush with the body.  I printed with PLA at 0.1mm layer height with 3 top / bottom layers and 3 perimeters, 50% infill.  No infill on the pin parts because I was having problems otherwise.

description.text:
Replacement part for a Audioline V110 Babyphone. The neck broke.
So I thought I give it a try in printing it, not sure if it would stand the "forces" when moving the camera on top. But it acutally stands it very well. Simply print it without support and mirror the part for the second side.
The holes need to be then drilled out with a 1mm and 3mm drill for the screws on the bottom and the cable guide. Kept it closed so printing is easier and results in a more robust print.

comments.text: That requires you to do something different on one side to avoid overhangs. This design allows sheer walls on both sides of the belt and because there is a lip on the inside, the bearing is held in place. title: Ipodium | Presentation Display for Your 3D Printed Artwork and Objects

description.text:
The Ipodium is a backlit, 3D Printed display stand for you to showcase all of your favourite 3D Printed artworks and objects.  
The Ipodium can be used as an open display case or a closed one. Simply scale the Ipodium up or down to suit your desired glass container profile.   
Upcycle your used glassware such as fish bowls, vases and even cups and glasses to suit the iPodium.   
The standard iPodium suits a 150mm (Internal Dimension) Glass Bell, scale the Ipodium according to the formula below.  
Scale % = Desired Glass Container Opening / 150mm.  
The iPodium works with a dismantled Ikea LED lamp using the LEDARE G9 bulb.   
Customise the text colour and lighting:   
Modify the 'text platform' with your own desired text and watch it light up with the led.  
Print the Light Disperse Platform in your desired colour and the text will glow to the colour you choose.   
Avooq Creations, Creation.

title: cC - Ekobots - Helix Windmill - Part II

description.text:
Parametrized HelixWindMill (Num of blades, height, angle.. and more)
Small wind collector model customizable.
Part II - Stator and Rotor Caution this model is very dangerous for children under 8 years, see intructions News
06/01/2015 - added more two customized models: 3 blades and 12 blades short. Very hard OpenSCAD processing sry, but I'll add more *.stl files with some interesting configurations. Please wait processing takes time.
The customizer does not support rendering the Stator and Rotor, better make offline.
Important: Not all combinations of settings are valid, the work of generating the blades by linear/rotate_extrude command is a hard work and may crash (CGAL). I'm still learning how to use in a friendly way the command library and its limitations (it's magnificent, yet complex and has to be well used) I express special thanks to GIMP, MeshLab and OpenSCAD teams for a great work. source of data: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_axis_wind_turbine
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windmill
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georges_Jean_Marie_Darrieus http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darrieus_wind_turbin
for future versions and Part II extension:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductrack

Caution this model is very dangerous for children, see below Warning: Small parts kill children if aspirated, see below This model is not a toy, it is inappropriate for children, the
parts are small and fragile, very easy to be broken and can cause
fatal injuries if aspirated by children. Please look into:
http:en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toy_safety
http:en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home_Safety_Council Part II - Stator and Rotor source of data: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vertical_axis_wind_turbine
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windmill
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georges_Jean_Marie_Darrieus http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darrieus_wind_turbin
for future versions and Part II:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductrack All parameters Important: Not all combinations of settings are valid, the work of generating the blades by linear/rotate_extrude command is a hard work and may crash (CGAL). I'm still learning how to use in a friendly way the command library and its limitations (it's magnificent, yet complex and has to be well used) Helix Wind Mill 01 - Print option Windmill/Cable support/Pole base
print_type=1; [0:Rotor, 1:Cable support, 2:Stator(base)]
02 - Scale factor of piece
ScaleXYZ=0.5; [0.2: 0.1: 1.0]
03 - Type of blade shape symetrical/asymetrical/sym.segmented
type=1; [0:symetrical, 1:asymetrical, , 2:sym.segmented]
04 - Total number of blades, #
numberBlades=03; [1: 0: 200]
05 - Height of blades, mm
heightWindmill=160; [10: 1: 400]
06 - Total angle of blades twist, degree
totalangleWindmill=160; [100: 1: 720]
07 - Distance around z axe of blade disk, mm (negative values cross axe)
df_translateXBlades=15; [-7: 1: 23]
08 - Distance around z axe of blade disk, mm (negative values cross axe)
df_translateYBlades=15; [-7: 1: 23] Heated Bed 09 - Heated Bed length, mm
df_lengthheatedBed=210; [100: 1: 600]
10 - Heated Bed width, mm
df_widthheatedBed=210; [100: 1: 600] WindMill - Advanced 11 - Distance around z axe of blade, mm (negative values cross axe)
df_translateXOneBlade=8; [-12: 1: 47]
12 - Distance around z axe of blade, mm (negative values cross axe)
df_translateYOneBlade=8; [-12: 1: 47]
13 - Individual blade rotation, degrees
rotateOneBlade=145; [10: 1: 400]
14 - Segments of symetrical segmented_wing, # (type sym.segmented)
holosegmentsBlade=16; [16: 1: 32] Advanced - Caution or crash run 15 - Number of extruded slices, #
slicesNum=20; [20: 1: 200]
16 - Number of object faces, #
S_fn=50; [20: 1: 200]

author: ozanbdr

description.text:
Place a tea light underneath to light up the spiral.
Just simply flip to the opposite direction and it is a vase! Perfect as a centerpiece at weddings or other special events! In the video I added LED lights underneath the spiral that automatically transition to different colors! The first two photos indicate which orientation is the Centerpiece versus the Vase. If you print this please take a picture! I am also selling printed versions of Voronoi Spiral Centerpiece/Vase on Etsy check it out!
https://www.etsy.com/listing/271381024/voronoi-spiral-centerpiecevase?ref=listing-shop-header-2 http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-create-a-3D-Printed-Voronoi-Spiral-Centerpi/ https://youtu.be/0eNcALHDtHU https://www.3dhubs.com/lehigh-valley/hubs/andrew

The Voronoi Spiral Centerpiece / Vase was originally drawn in AutoCAD and then modeled using Rhino. The pictures at the end of the gallery show some of the key steps I took to creating the digital file. This was the second iteration from my other creation, the 'Voronoi Night Light' http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:855728 The full instructions on my workflow of the creation is located at http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-create-a-3D-Printed-Voronoi-Spiral-Centerpi/

This thing is a mouse trap car made by a laser cutter, the files below (odg, cst) are open office and roland cut studio files, each type has the same cuts needed to make the car. This car is not specifically made for speed or distance but more of a solid base for a mouse trap of any kind. ALSO! the way i was able to fit the pencils into the CD was the adapter made by MJCbull, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8300

I made the car with a base for the trap, 2 sides to act as axel holders, and whatever you are able to use as the axels itself, i used a pencil and a small rod. for the wheels I used CDs and small toy car wheels, what you want is a very large difference in wheel size to make the pull of the mouse trap larger and in doing so, faster. after the car is assembled, you will need a larger arm to pull the string at a more fast, and drawn out pace. that is what i made the clamp for the arm for; it allows u to attach a pencil (very common to find and replace). and in doing so you have just finished a mouse trap car! wind that bad boy up and give it a spin. ( you may want to put some type of grips on wheels for more traction)

title: Replicator 2/2X hinges and handle for the lid

description.text:
For the price you might expect a Replicator 2X would come with a hinge for the vacuum formed (and very welcome) lid. (Wait, what am I thinking...)  
Here is a somewhat delux / overengineered version of hinges and handle for this model. It uses ball bearing for the hinge and will support the lid nicely when open.   
You could get away with printed hinge bearings but it would not be as "nice". (And we all know how important it is to be nice).  But for those who wish to tweak, there are source design files in rhino3D and STEP formats.  
Works like a bought one. Enjoy.

There are STL's for the lower machine clip (Hinge A) and the upper hinge (Hinge B) and handle. There is a separate STL for the hinge pivot as this needs to be quite strong.   
The Hinges A/B and handle can be printed in whatever you like, but the pivot will do best in PLA with 100% infill.   Hinge B has some print support structured in the design to prevent sagging of the important hinge pivot area. These break away without difficulty like any support material. It MUST however be printed with slicer support as well. Other than the pivot STL, the STLs all have "stick down" flanges to minimise the potential for print curling. Works a treat.  
The handle has matching plates for the other side of the lid. When screwed together these distribute the screw pressure to provide a secure fit without the possibility of tearing / distortion of the hole. (Which may occur with a simple screw). Looks nicer too; and as noted above, nice is nice.  
The ball bearing are easily obtainable 22mm OD/ 8mm ID / 7mm depth - used in roller blades everywhere... Which is why I have a bunch lying around the house which therefore get preferentially designed into things. (Just nip out and nick one or two from your kid's blades; they'll never notice!)  
The upper hinge (B) will support the lid when open without problems and sits snug through the lid motion. I have however chosen to bond it to the lid with double sided tape. This ensures the hinges don't move from side to side as you "flip the lid". I had considered using magnets in the A hinge to secure them to the machine upper surface, but the tape approach has the benefit of being simple and eliminating upper hinge rattle.  
UPDATE 11 July 2013  
While no problem has been reported with printing, it seems there are problems with loading some the STLs into other programmes. There is a new ZIP file with refreshed STL's which check out clean in Netfabb  
UPDATE 30 July 2013  
Have slimmed down Hinga A in a tweaked version for those experiencing print head collisions. (I have not had this problem, but this will avoid it...)

author: kosscablemod

title: HPI Wheely King Servo Saver A392 (from set 85260)

description.text:
HPI Wheely King is an entry level 1:12 scale RC monster truck.  Its steering servo mechanism contains a sacrificial split ring coupling called a "servo saver".  When you hit a tree with your front wheel the coupling breaks and you get to buy a $11 set of parts (85260) to replace just that one small plastic piece.  
After going through 2 of those, I measured and printed the next one.  Then a couple more.  A coupler out of PLA seems to work fine.  It holds up during normal use and breaks on impact, just like the original part.

• Print.
  • Install.

author: Ghiotto

description.text:
This is a bracket to mount any of the GoPro compatible cameras to a rollbar.    It is pretty solid compared with the alternatives.  The closer the camera is to the bar, the less vibration it gets.  
The design is completely parametric, so you could customize it for your use case.  It should work for a handlebar mount, too.

Print with support.  Carve and/or file out the support material from between the plates of the mount head.  Use an M5 nut and an M5 GoPro screw for the camera end and two sets of M6 fasteners for the rollbar end.

author: NHSE

description.text:
This is a filter for a small pond / fountain pump to allow it to be used directly in a pond and filter out weed, tadpoles and general grot which would clog up the impeller.
This is not for the really small pump type which have an inbuilt filter; this is the next size up with a tubular 12mm o.d. inlet and no filter - See the spec label photo.

Print this with no support and with the inlet side down as per the STL. The roof is a good test of your printer's bridging capability; a head fan helps here. Don't worry about stringing between the holes as it will help the filter action.
The inlet is intentionally slightly undersize. Use a sharp edge to scrape the inside to give a good twisting fit, but carefully as the filter is a bit brittle (at least it is with PLA).
Estadio de los Cármenes

description.text: scout cross

Ever drop a box of nails and wish you had a easier way to clean them all up... well so have I... All you'll need is a 12" piece of 1"x 2" and an old broom handle... plus about 40 (9.5mm x 2.5mm) magnets... a drop of glue to hold them in place and place a piece box tape over for easy clean-up and your done.

All you'll need is a 12" piece of 1"x 2" and an old broom handle... plus about 40 (9.5mm x 2.5mm) magnets... a drop of glue to hold them in place and place a piece box tape over for easy clean-up and your done.

title: Sony Xperia Charging Dock (works as a stand for iPad Mini too!) with coin holder

description.text:
This is a charging dock for Sony Xperia phone, the charging cable can be brought on eBay, the coin stack will weight it down with some heft (~250 grams), it's sized for 1 pound coins, but seems fine with 2 pence.  
Will also fit the iPad Mini. And of course the angle your Table/Phone rest on is the magical 70 degrees, like in Apple store (^_^)  
For any other tablet, thickness has to be less than 8.3mm

title: Ormerod fan duct for dc42's PCB

description.text:
This is a simple fan duct to allow dc42's sensor PCB to be fitted. The duct discharges to the side and not to the bed. I have converted my printer to dual nozzle with the quick set nozzles and since fitting have had trouble with the filaments sticking in the hotend which I guess is due to over cooling with my old style fan duct. Since fitting the problem has gone away, but time will tell.
NB RRP's kit includes what is basically a fan mount which may have been done to avoid such a problem.

The heatsink fits into the back such that it is covered at the top and to the PCB side, leaving the opposite side open. The heatsink is mounted with the fins horizontal to allow the air to discharge to the side. Two screws go through the top two fan holes and hold it to the duct with two nuts. The heatsink requires that a little is snipped off the second fin from the top to allow clearance for the nuts. The long bolts go through the fan, fan duct, heatsink and into the quickset nozzle mount which clamps to the back of the heat sink.   
The PCB is mounted on the end on the two posts which will need drilling through before mounting, with a 2mm drill, allowing the screws to self tap. NB there are two dimples to indicated where the holes should go.  
For print cooling I have a fan mounted on the Z axis bearing block with iamburny's excellent bracket. See Ormerod on Thingverse
